title: Mixed connectives
content: This section gathers theorems of propositional calculus which use (either in their statement or proof) mixed connectives (at least conjunction and disjunction). As noted in the "note on definitions" in the section comment for logical equivalence, some theorem statements may contain for instance only conjunction or only disjunction, but both definitions are used in their proofs to make them shorter (this is exemplified in ~ orim12d versus ~ orim12dALT ). These theorems are mostly grouped at the beginning of this section. The family of theorems starting with ~ animorl focus on the relation between conjunction and disjunction and can be seen as the starting point of mixed connectives in statements. This sectioning is not rigorously true, since for instance the section begins with ~ jaao and related theorems.

blocks.name: jaao
blocks.content: Inference conjoining and disjoining the antecedents of two implications. (Contributed by NM, 30-Sep-1999.)

blocks.name: jaoa
blocks.content: Inference disjoining and conjoining the antecedents of two implications. (Contributed by Stefan Allan, 1-Nov-2008.)

blocks.name: jaoian
blocks.content: Inference disjoining the antecedents of two implications. (Contributed by NM, 23-Oct-2005.)

blocks.name: jaodan
blocks.content: Deduction disjoining the antecedents of two implications. (Contributed by NM, 14-Oct-2005.)

blocks.name: mpjaodan
blocks.content: Eliminate a disjunction in a deduction. A translation of natural deduction rule ` \/ ` E ( ` \/ ` elimination), see ~ natded . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 29-May-2016.)

blocks.name: xor
blocks.content: Two ways to express exclusive disjunction ( ~ df-xor ). Theorem *5.22 of [WhiteheadRussell] p. 124. (Contributed by NM, 3-Jan-2005.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 22-Jan-2013.)

blocks.name: nbi2
blocks.content: Two ways to express "exclusive or". (Contributed by NM, 3-Jan-2005.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 24-Jan-2013.)

blocks.name: xordi
blocks.content: Conjunction distributes over exclusive-or, using ` -. ( ph <-> ps ) ` to express exclusive-or. This is one way to interpret the distributive law of multiplication over addition in modulo 2 arithmetic. This is not necessarily true in intuitionistic logic, though ~ anxordi does hold in it. (Contributed by NM, 3-Oct-2008.)

blocks.name: ecase2d
blocks.content: Deduction for elimination by cases. (Contributed by NM, 21-Apr-1994.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 22-Dec-2012.)
blocks.origin:
thm ecase2d(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3, wff w4) {
  |- wi(w0, w1)
  -| wi(w0, w2)
  -| wi(w0, wn(wa(w2, w3)))
  -| wi(w0, wn(wa(w2, w4)))
  -| wi(w0, wo(w1, wo(w3, w4)))
} = {
  mpjaod(w0, w1, w1, wo(w3, w4))
  idd(w0, w1)
  jaod(w0, w3, w4, w1)
  mpand(w0, w3, w1, w2)
  pm2.21d(w0, wa(w2, w3), w1)
  mpand(w0, w4, w1, w2)
  pm2.21d(w0, wa(w2, w4), w1)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm ecase2d(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3, wff w4) {
  ⊢ (w0 → w1)
  ⊣ (w0 → w2)
  ⊣ (w0 → ¬(w2 ∧ w3))
  ⊣ (w0 → ¬(w2 ∧ w4))
  ⊣ (w0 →(w1 ∨(w3 ∨ w4)))
} = {
  mpjaod(w0, w1, w1, (w3 ∨ w4))
  idd(w0, w1)
  jaod(w0, w3, w4, w1)
  mpand(w0, w3, w1, w2)
  pm2.21d(w0, (w2 ∧ w3), w1)
  mpand(w0, w4, w1, w2)
  pm2.21d(w0, (w2 ∧ w4), w1)
}

blocks.name: ecase3
blocks.content: Inference for elimination by cases. (Contributed by NM, 23-Mar-1995.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 26-Nov-2012.)

blocks.content: Deduction for elimination by cases. (Contributed by NM, 8-Oct-2012.)

blocks.name: ccase
blocks.content: Inference for combining cases. (Contributed by NM, 29-Jul-1999.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 6-Jan-2013.)

blocks.name: ccased
blocks.content: Deduction for combining cases. (Contributed by NM, 9-May-2004.)
blocks.origin:
thm ccased(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3, wff w4, wff w5) {
  |- wi(w0, wi(wa(wo(w1, w2), wo(w3, w4)), w5))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wa(w1, w3), w5))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wa(w2, w3), w5))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wa(w1, w4), w5))
  -| wi(w0, wi(wa(w2, w4), w5))
} = {
  com12(w0, wa(wo(w1, w2), wo(w3, w4)), w5)
  ccase(w1, w2, w3, w4, wi(w0, w5))
  com12(wa(w1, w3), w0, w5)
  com12(wa(w2, w3), w0, w5)
  com12(wa(w1, w4), w0, w5)
  com12(wa(w2, w4), w0, w5)
}

blocks.name: ccase2
blocks.content: Inference for combining cases. (Contributed by NM, 29-Jul-1999.)

blocks.name: 4cases
blocks.content: Inference eliminating two antecedents from the four possible cases that result from their true/false combinations. (Contributed by NM, 25-Oct-2003.)

blocks.content: Deduction eliminating two antecedents from the four possible cases that result from their true/false combinations. (Contributed by NM, 19-Mar-2013.)

blocks.name: cases
blocks.content: Case disjunction according to the value of ` ph ` . (Contributed by NM, 25-Apr-2019.)

blocks.name: dedlem0a
blocks.content: Lemma for an alternate version of weak deduction theorem. (Contributed by NM, 2-Apr-1994.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 7-May-2011.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 4-Dec-2012.)

blocks.name: dedlem0b
blocks.content: Lemma for an alternate version of weak deduction theorem. (Contributed by NM, 2-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: dedlema
blocks.content: Lemma for weak deduction theorem. See also ~ ifptru . (Contributed by NM, 26-Jun-2002.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 7-May-2011.)

blocks.name: dedlemb
blocks.content: Lemma for weak deduction theorem. See also ~ ifpfal . (Contributed by NM, 15-May-1999.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 7-May-2011.)

blocks.name: cases2
blocks.content: Case disjunction according to the value of ` ph ` . (Contributed by BJ, 6-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 28-Feb-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm cases2(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wb(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)))
} = {
  3bitr4ri(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wi(w0, wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0)))), wi(wn(w0), wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0))))), wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0))))
  pm4.83(w0, wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0))))
  anbi12i(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2), wi(w0, wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0)))), wi(wn(w0), wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0)))))
  pm5.74i(w0, w1, wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0))))
  dedlema(w0, w1, w2)
  pm5.74i(wn(w0), w2, wo(wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0))))
  dedlemb(w0, w2, w1)
  orbi12i(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2), wa(w1, w0), wa(w2, wn(w0)))
  ancom(w0, w1)
  ancom(wn(w0), w2)
}

blocks.name: cases2ALT
blocks.content: Alternate proof of ~ cases2 , not using ~ dedlema or ~ dedlemb . (Contributed by BJ, 6-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 2-Jan-2020.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm cases2ALT(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2) {
  |- wb(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)))
} = {
  impbii(wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)))
  jaoi(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2), wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)))
  jca(wa(w0, w1), wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2))
  pm3.4(w0, w1)
  adantr(w0, w1, wi(wn(w0), w2))
  pm2.24(w0, w2)
  jca(wa(wn(w0), w2), wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2))
  adantr(wn(w0), w2, wi(w0, w1))
  pm2.21(w0, w1)
  pm3.4(wn(w0), w2)
  pm2.61ian(wa(wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2)), wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)), w0)
  adantrr(w0, wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2), wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)))
  orcd(wa(w0, wi(w0, w1)), wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2))
  imdistani(w0, wi(w0, w1), w1)
  pm2.27(w0, w1)
  adantrl(wn(w0), wi(w0, w1), wi(wn(w0), w2), wo(wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2)))
  olcd(wa(wn(w0), wi(wn(w0), w2)), wa(w0, w1), wa(wn(w0), w2))
  imdistani(wn(w0), wi(wn(w0), w2), w2)
  pm2.27(wn(w0), w2)
}

blocks.name: dfbi3
blocks.content: An alternate definition of the biconditional. Theorem *5.23 of [WhiteheadRussell] p. 124. (Contributed by NM, 27-Jun-2002.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 3-Nov-2013.) (Proof shortened by NM, 29-Oct-2021.)

blocks.name: pm5.24
blocks.content: Theorem *5.24 of [WhiteheadRussell] p. 124. (Contributed by NM, 3-Jan-2005.)

blocks.name: 4exmid
blocks.content: The disjunction of the four possible combinations of two wffs and their negations is always true. A four-way excluded middle (see ~ exmid ). (Contributed by David Abernethy, 28-Jan-2014.) (Proof shortened by NM, 29-Oct-2021.)

blocks.name: consensus
blocks.content: The consensus theorem. This theorem and its dual (with ` \/ ` and ` /\ ` interchanged) are commonly used in computer logic design to eliminate redundant terms from Boolean expressions. Specifically, we prove that the term ` ( ps /\ ch ) ` on the left-hand side is redundant. (Contributed by NM, 16-May-2003.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 13-May-2011.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 20-Jan-2013.)

blocks.name: pm4.42
blocks.content: Theorem *4.42 of [WhiteheadRussell] p. 119. See also ~ ifpid . (Contributed by Roy F. Longton, 21-Jun-2005.)

blocks.name: prlem1
blocks.content: A specialized lemma for set theory (to derive the Axiom of Pairing). (Contributed by NM, 18-Oct-1995.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 13-May-2011.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 5-Jan-2013.)

blocks.name: prlem2
blocks.content: A specialized lemma for set theory (to derive the Axiom of Pairing). (Contributed by NM, 21-Jun-1993.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 13-May-2011.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 9-Dec-2012.)

blocks.name: oplem1
blocks.content: A specialized lemma for set theory (ordered pair theorem). (Contributed by NM, 18-Oct-1995.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 8-Dec-2012.)
blocks.origin:
thm oplem1(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3, wff w4) {
  |- wi(w0, w1)
  -| wi(w0, wo(w1, w2))
  -| wi(w0, wo(w3, w4))
  -| wb(w1, w3)
  -| wi(w2, wb(w3, w4))
} = {
  sylibr(w0, w1, w3)
  pm2.18d(w0, w3)
  syl6(w0, wn(w3), w3, wa(w2, w4))
  jcad(w0, wn(w3), w2, w4)
  syl5bir(w0, wn(w3), w2, wn(w1))
  notbii(w1, w3)
  ord(w0, w1, w2)
  ord(w0, w3, w4)
  biimpar(w2, w4, w3)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm oplem1(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3, wff w4) {
  ⊢ (w0 → w1)
  ⊣ (w0 →(w1 ∨ w2))
  ⊣ (w0 →(w3 ∨ w4))
  ⊣ (w1 ↔ w3)
  ⊣ (w2 →(w3 ↔ w4))
} = {
  sylibr(w0, w1, w3)
  pm2.18d(w0, w3)
  syl6(w0, ¬ w3, w3, (w2 ∧ w4))
  jcad(w0, ¬ w3, w2, w4)
  syl5bir(w0, ¬ w3, w2, ¬ w1)
  notbii(w1, w3)
  ord(w0, w1, w2)
  ord(w0, w3, w4)
  biimpar(w2, w4, w3)
}

blocks.name: dn1
blocks.content: A single axiom for Boolean algebra known as DN_1. See McCune, Veroff, Fitelson, Harris, Feist, Wos, _Short single axioms for Boolean algebra_, Journal of Automated Reasoning, 29(1):1--16, 2002. ( ~ https://www.cs.unm.edu/~~mccune/papers/basax/v12.pdf ). (Contributed by Jeff Hankins, 3-Jul-2009.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 13-May-2011.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 6-Jan-2013.)
blocks.origin:
thm dn1(wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3) {
  |- wb(wn(wo(wn(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2)), wn(wo(w0, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3)))))))), w2)
} = {
  3bitrri(wn(wo(wn(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2)), wn(wo(w0, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3)))))))), w2, wa(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, w2)), wa(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3)))))))
  bitri(w2, wa(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, w2)), wo(w2, wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0)))
  biorfi(w2, wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0))
  mpbi(wn(wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0)), wi(wn(wo(w0, w1)), wn(w0)))
  pm2.45(w0, w1)
  imnan(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0)
  bitri(wo(w2, wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0)), wa(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, w2)), wo(wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0), w2))
  orcom(w2, wa(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0))
  ordir(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w0, w2)
  anbi2i(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, w2), wo(w0, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3))))))
  orbi2i(w0, w2, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3)))))
  bitri(w2, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3)))), wa(w2, wo(w2, w3)))
  pm4.45(w2, w3)
  anor(w2, wo(w2, w3))
  anor(wo(wn(wo(w0, w1)), w2), wo(w0, wn(wo(wn(w2), wn(wo(w2, w3))))))
}

blocks.name: bianir
blocks.content: A closed form of ~ mpbir , analogous to ~ pm2.27 (assertion). (Contributed by Jonathan Ben-Naim, 3-Jun-2011.) (Proof shortened by Roger Witte, 17-Aug-2020.)

blocks.name: jaoi2
blocks.content: Inference removing a negated conjunct in a disjunction of an antecedent if this conjunct is part of the disjunction. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 3-Nov-2017.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 21-Sep-2018.)

blocks.name: jaoi3
blocks.content: Inference separating a disjunct of an antecedent. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 25-May-2018.)

blocks.name: ornld
blocks.content: Selecting one statement from a disjunction if one of the disjuncted statements is false. (Contributed by AV, 6-Sep-2018.) (Proof shortened by AV, 13-Oct-2018.) (Proof shortened by Wolf Lammen, 19-Jan-2020.)
